CustomTaglets Documentation v1.0

com.customtaglet
Class Prettify

java.lang.Object
  com.customtaglet.Prettify

public final class Prettify
extends java.lang.Object

THIS IS NOT A TAGLET!

This is just documented here for the sake of explaining the pretty printing feature available in this project.

Since more conventional way to change the output of the Javadoc would require much efforts to rebuild a whole doclet (and most available do not properly work), the approach here is dirty, simple but efficient.

A file called prettify.py, written in Python language, can be executed to "FIX" the javadoc HTML code to accept the syntax highlighting feature of code documentation within javadoc.

This makes use of the open-source project called google-code-prettify, available at: http://google-code-prettify.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/README.html

Instructions

  • (1) Copy prettify.py to your project's root directory
  • (2) Create the Javadoc documentation, using the <pre class="prettify"> tagging for code documentation in java files.
  • (3) Execute prettify.py to make the changes in the HTML docs.
  • (4) Done!
Note: execute, from command-line: prettify.py --help for additional details on this script.

Since:
1.0
Author:
Bruno Braga <bruno.braga@gmail.com>

Method Detail

example

public void example()
This is an example using javadoc code documentation that is to be generated by prettify.py script. 
      //
      // Javadoc does not support "/ * * /" type of commenting. 
      //
      public class Foo {
      
          public Foo() {}
          
          public String toUpper(String text) {
          
              // simple example to return upper-case
              // formatting of a particular string
              return text.toUpperCase();
          
          }
      }
